articles.headline: Obama to Toughen Rules on Emissions and Mileage
articles.snippet: The Obama administration plans to combine California’s tough new auto-emissions rules with existing fuel economy limits to create a single new national standard.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration plans to combine California’s tough new auto-emissions rules with existing fuel economy limits to create a single new national standard.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama will announce tough new nationwide rules for automobile emissions and mileage standards on Tuesday, embracing standards that California has sought to enact for years over the objections of the auto industry and the Bush administration.

articles.headline: Passengers’ Advocates See Progress
articles.snippet: Legislation in Congress calls on airlines to provide certain services for passengers stuck on the runway, but battles continue over whether to permit them to get off the plane while they wait.
articles.abstract: Legislation in Congress calls on airlines to provide certain services for passengers stuck on the runway, but battles continue over whether to permit them to get off the plane while they wait.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a nearly a decade of failed efforts to win rights for airline passengers, advocates may finally score some modest gains.

articles.headline: Trustee Sues Hedge Funds Over Losses to Madoff
articles.snippet: The latest lawsuit focuses on the Fairfield Greenwich Group, which topped the list of losers in the Madoff Ponzi scheme with more than $7 billion invested in the fraud.
articles.abstract: The latest lawsuit focuses on the Fairfield Greenwich Group, which topped the list of losers in the Madoff Ponzi scheme with more than $7 billion invested in the fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hedge fund family that topped the list of losers in Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, with more than $7 billion sunk in the immense fraud, has been sued by the trustee overseeing the search for assets in the case.

articles.headline: An Election in India Buoys Stocks
articles.snippet: Executives and economists predicted that the Congress Party’s mandate would lead to nothing less than the narrowing of China’s economic lead over India.
articles.abstract: Executives and economists predicted that the Congress Party’s mandate would lead to nothing less than the narrowing of China’s economic lead over India.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  Investors in India, exuberant over the ruling party’s commanding win in the country’s monthlong election, sent stocks rocketing Monday  so fast and so far that they forced the temporary shutdown of Indian stock exchanges.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Ex-U.S. Envoy May Take Key Role in Afghan Government
articles.snippet: Zalmay Khalilzad, a former ambassador to Afghanistan, could assume a powerful position under a plan he is discussing with the Afghan president, officials said.
articles.abstract: Zalmay Khalilzad, a former ambassador to Afghanistan, could assume a powerful position under a plan he is discussing with the Afghan president, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Zalmay Khalilzad, who was President George W. Bush’s ambassador to Afghanistan, could assume a powerful, unelected position inside the Afghan government under a plan he is discussing with Hamid Karzai, the Afghan president, according to senior American and Afghan officials.

articles.headline: Wall St. Firm Draws Scrutiny as U.S. Adviser
articles.snippet: Questions are being raised over an apparent conflict between BlackRock’s role as a government adviser and its profits as manager of troubled assets.
articles.abstract: Questions are being raised over an apparent conflict between BlackRock’s role as a government adviser and its profits as manager of troubled assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial crisis has ravaged many a Wall Street giant, but it has also produced a handful of winners. BlackRock, a money manager that is much admired but little known outside financial circles, is fast emerging as one of the nation’s financial powerhouses.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Credit Card Industry Aims to Profit From Sterling Payers
articles.snippet: With Congress on the verge of limiting penalties on delinquent borrowers, credit card companies are expected to turn to their best customers to make up the difference.
articles.abstract: With Congress on the verge of limiting penalties on delinquent borrowers, credit card companies are expected to turn to their best customers to make up the difference.
articles.lead_paragraph: Credit cards have long been a very good deal for people who pay their bills on time and in full. Even as card companies imposed punitive fees and penalties on those late with their payments, the best customers racked up cash-back rewards, frequent-flier miles and other perks in recent years.

articles.headline: Seeking a Missing Link, and a Mass Audience
articles.snippet: A media pile-on will announce a 47-million-year-old primate.
articles.abstract: A media pile-on will announce a 47-million-year-old primate.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is science for the Mediacene age.

articles.headline: Home Depot Girds for Continued Weakness
articles.snippet: The leadership of Home Depot has decided to move from a culture of expansion to one that is less vulnerable to consumer and credit slowdowns.
articles.abstract: The leadership of Home Depot has decided to move from a culture of expansion to one that is less vulnerable to consumer and credit slowdowns.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA  When the collapse of Lehman Brothers froze the credit markets last September, Carol Tome quickly ordered hundreds of Home Depot’s store managers to transfer all their spare cash to headquarters  literally cleaning out their registers and each store’s safe.

articles.headline: Efforts to Repay Bailouts May Undercut Benefit for Taxpayers
articles.snippet: The price that the government accepts for warrants to buy bank stock could determine whether taxpayers make a profit or a loss.
articles.abstract: The price that the government accepts for warrants to buy bank stock could determine whether taxpayers make a profit or a loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans were promised a reward for rescuing the nation’s banks. In return for all those bailouts, the banks essentially granted stock options to the government  a potential jackpot for taxpayers once the crisis blew over.

articles.headline: In Britain, Scandal Flows From Modest Request
articles.snippet: The biggest scandal to hit the British House of Commons in decades began with an American freelance writer’s request under a new freedom of information act.
articles.abstract: The biggest scandal to hit the British House of Commons in decades began with an American freelance writer’s request under a new freedom of information act.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  It began modestly enough back in 2005, when an American freelance writer and journalism teacher living in London, Heather Brooke, entered a request under Britain’s newly promulgated freedom of information act for details of the expense claims of British members of Parliament.
